section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Ecosystems

embeddable.name: 1. A computer simulation ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. A computer simulation models a population of worms which feeds on "grass" in a field. The worms derive energy from consuming grass and use up energy crawling and reproducing. They have a limited lifespan. What variable would have the greatest impact on the long-term number of worms?

choice.choice: a. initial number of worms
b. rate of growth of the grass
c. reproduction rate of the worms
d. energy reserve of a worm

embeddable.name: 2. Here is a graph of a populati ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. Here is a graph of a population limited by a food supply. Which statement is true?

choice.choice: a. The population is not stable.
b. The final population depends on the initial number of individuals.
c. The population size affects the amount of food at any given time.
d. There must also be a predator to make the graph look this way.

embeddable.name: 3. A computer simulation ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. A computer simulation models an ecosystem consisting of wolves, sheep, and grass. The sheep eat grass and the wolves eat sheep. Their populations levels are shown in the graph. What is the best description for the cause of the large population of sheep circled in the graph?

choice.choice: a. The number of wolves had decreased to their lowest levels just prior to that.
b. The number of wolves had decreased and the grass supply had been very good.
c. The birth rate of the sheep had increased to a point where they made up for the loss of sheep to wolves.
d. The combination of lack of wolves , increased birth rate of sheep, and the large supply of grass at that time.

embeddable.name: 4. A computer simulation ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. A computer simulation models an ecosystem consisting of wolves, sheep, and grass. The sheep eat grass and the wolves eat sheep. Their populations levels are shown in the graph. What is the best explanation for the increase in grass circled in the graph?

choice.choice: a. Unusually warm and wet weather
b. Large decrease in the number of sheep
c. Significant increase in the number of wolves
d. Significant increase in the growth rate of the grass

embeddable.name: 5. A computer simulation ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. A computer simulation models an ecosystem consisting of wolves, sheep, and grass. The sheep eat grass and the wolves eat sheep. Their populations levels are shown in the graph. What would be the best explanation for the tremendous increase in sheep?

choice.choice: a. The extended period of good grass growth
b. An dramatic increase in the birth rate of the sheep
c. A decrease in the wolf population
d. Extinction of the wolf population

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Evolution

embeddable.name: 1. A computer simulation ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. A computer simulation has a population of sheep with three different genetic variations in their teeth: "Better teeth" (red), "average teeth" (brown), and "worse teeth" (black). The model is run three times, representing the population over many generations, with the results shown below. What can you conclude is true in the model about the effect of the genetic variation?

choice.choice: a. The model does not represent what could happen in a real population.
b. Natural selection leads to "better teeth".
c. The teeth variation has no effect on the survival and reproduction rate of the sheep.
d. Natural selection would play a role if the model were run longer.

embeddable.name: 2. What is not a good example ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. What is not a good example of a possible selection pressure?

choice.choice: a. Losing good eyesight in old age.
b. Plentiful food is available only for a brief part of the year.
c. Brightly colored berries are more attractive to birds.
d. Light-colored fur coats are more valuable in the market.

embeddable.name: 3. Moose may have evolved ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. Moose may have evolved to become larger because they could better protect themselves from predators. If so, why didn’t moose just keep getting bigger and bigger? Pick the answer that seems most plausible.

choice.choice: a. Not enough time has gone by.
b. A large body requires more food.
c. Snow would limit movement of large bodies.
d. Moose have always been that size, since the beginning.

embeddable.name: 4. Which bird's beak is
embeddable.prompt: 4. Which bird's beak is not suited for eating seeds on dry land?

embeddable.name: 5. In this graph taken from ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. In this graph taken from a simulation, a few mutated sheep (blue) have been added to the flock without the mutation (black). What could be said about this mutation, based on the graph of population over many generations?

choice.choice: a. The mutation had no significant impact on the kinds of sheep in the flock over time.
b. The mutation was favorable but reduced the size of the flock.
c. The mutation offered some sort of advantage in reproduction or survival.
d. The mutation had no advantages.

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Human Body

embeddable.name: 1. What part of your body ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. What part of your body would be the warmest?

choice.choice: a. palm of hand
b. ankle
c. cheek
d. armpit

embeddable.name: 2. What part of the body ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. What part of the body controls respiration rate?

choice.choice: a. heart
b. lungs
c. liver
d. brain

embeddable.name: What physiological activity ...
embeddable.prompt: What physiological activity does this graph best represent?

choice.choice: a. heartrate
b. breathing rate
c. blood pressure
d. skin temperature

embeddable.name: 4. What would be the most ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. What would be the most likely response to your body temperature when placing your hand in extremely cold ice water?

choice.choice: a. Your pulse rate would speed up to pump more blood into the extremities raising the temperature.
b. Your pulse rate would speed up to pump more blood into the extremities to maintain your body temperature.
c. Your pulse rate would slow down to conserve energy within the core of your body to maintain your temperature.
d. Your pulse rate would not be effected by the cold water emersion of just your hand.

embeddable.name: 5. Why would your fingertips ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. Why would your fingertips have a lower surface temperature than your neck?

choice.choice: a. The skin is more calloused.
b. Your fingers move more.
c. Blood vessels are nearer to the surface in your neck.
d. Your neck has hair.

embeddable.prompt: 1. What part of your body would be the warmest?

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Molecular Motion

embeddable.name: 1. In this diagram of osmosis, ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. In this diagram of osmosis, which shows two areas separated by a membrane, which answer best describes the motion of the molecules?

choice.choice: a. Carbon dioxide is leaving the cell and oxygen is entering the cell.
b. Oxygen is leaving the cell and carbon dioxide is entering the cell.
c. Both carbon dioxide and oxygen are entering the cell.
d. Both carbon dioxide and oxygen are leaving the cell.

embeddable.name: 2. This diagram represents ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. This diagram represents a red blood cell with oxygen molecules (yellow) both inside the cell (pink background) and outside the cell (blue background). The concentration of the oxygen molecules outside the cell is greater than the concentration inside. Which answer best describes the motion of the oxygen molecules?

choice.choice: a. The oxygen molecules within the cell will leave the cell being drawn out by the higher concentration.
b. The oxygen molecules within the cell will remain at a constant level since they have reached the right concentration.
c. The oxygen molecules outside the cell will cross the membrane of the red cell until both concentrations are nearly at equilibrium.
d. The oxygen molecules inside the cell will cross through the membrane to the outside until both sides are nearly at equilibrium.

embeddable.name: 3. This diagram shows a cell ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. This diagram shows a cell wall separating inside (right) from outside (left). Why is the cell shrinking?

choice.choice: a. The concentration of water is greater on the outside of the cell.
b. The concentration of salt is greater on the outside of the cell.
c. The concentration of water is greater on the inside of the cell.
d. The concentration of salt is greater on the inside of the cell.

embeddable.name: 4. Over time biological systems ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. Over time biological systems have evolved to help maximize and/or control the movement of important molecules and ions into and out of the cell. Which of the following is not an important factor affecting this diffusion rate?

choice.choice: a. concentration
b. temperature
c. surface area
d. molecular pumps

embeddable.name: 5. The diagram shows a cell ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. The diagram shows a cell membrane pump (yellow). What is the source of energy that activates the cell membrane pump?

choice.choice: a. ADP
b. ATP
c. P
d. Ca

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Protein Structure

embeddable.name: 1. In this ladder model ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. In this ladder model of a DNA molecule, what are the five elements that make up the molecule?

choice.choice: a. A, C, N, S, O
b. C, H, O, N, P
c. C, H, Cl, P, H
d. K, P, C, O, H

embeddable.name: 2. In this diagram taken ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. In this diagram taken from the DNA to Proteins activity, which nucleotide is unique to the messenger RNA?

choice.choice: a. A
b. T
c. U
d. C

embeddable.name: 3. Where does the process ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. Where does the process of transcription [making messenger RNA] take place within a cell?

choice.choice: a. cytoplasm
b. nucleus
c. Golgi bodies
d. ribosome

embeddable.name: 4. What part of a cell joins ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. What part of a cell joins with the messenger RNA in a process called “Translation” to produce a chain of amino acids into proteins?

choice.choice: a. nucleus
b. ribosome
c. mitochondria
d. vacuoles

choice.choice: a. nucleus
b. ribosome
c. mitchondria
d. vacuoles

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Populations

embeddable.name: 1. A computer simulation ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. A computer simulation models sheep that eat grass. If they gain enough energy from the grass, they can reproduce; if not, they die. The graph shows the population over many generations. Why is the population stable?

choice.choice: a. It started with the right number of sheep.
b. The amount of grass is constant.
c. The sheep sense when to stop eating.
d. The grass and sheep populations limit each other.

embeddable.name: 2. If the climate of the ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. If the climate of the earth continues to get warmer, no matter the cause, what is the most likely impact on populations of animals in your state?

choice.choice: a. Over time the population of animals will change with some life forms going extinct or leaving and others moving in and populating the habitats left vacant.
b. No significant change will occur because the life forms will adapt to the changing conditions over time and we will shelter those that cannot adapt.
c. The change will be significant and dramatic with most of the life forms in our state going extinct
d. New life forms will emerge and destroy the habitat of the life forms in the area.

embeddable.name: 3.Which population is most ...
embeddable.prompt: 3.Which population is most likely to go extinct?

choice.choice: a. a large population with lots of genetic variation
b. a large population with no genetic variation
c. a small population with lots of genetic variation
d. a small population with no genetic variation

embeddable.name: 4. A computer simulation ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. A computer simulation models a population of rabbits that eat grass. What does the graph show happens over time with the population of rabbits and the amount of grass?

choice.choice: a. As the rabbit population grew so did the amount of grass.
b. As the rabbit population grew the amount of grass decreased, and vice versa.
c. The graph shows no relationship between the amount of rabbits and the amount of grass.
d. The graph shows that the size of the rabbit population would grow forever.

embeddable.name: 5. If an animal was introduced ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. If an animal was introduced into an area where there was no predator and there was a significant food supply available, what would probably happen to the population?

choice.choice: a. The population would remain stable until an introduced variable reduced the population.
b. The population would increase until the available food supply ran out, and then it would go extinct.
c. The population would go through several growth and decline cycles depending on available food.
d. Without a predator, the population could never be stable.

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Atomic Structure

embeddable.name: 1. As you move down a column ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. As you move down a column within the Periodic Table what happens to the size of the atom of each element?

choice.choice: a. The atoms get larger.
b. The atoms get smaller.
c. The atoms do not change size.
d. The atom change in size from large to small and back to large.

embeddable.name: 2. What happens to the electrone ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. What happens to the electronegativity of an element as you move from left to right across a period and up a column of a group?

choice.choice: a. It decreases.
b. It increases.
c. It increases across the period and decreases up a group.
d. It decreases across the period and increases up a group.

embeddable.name: 3. The shape of an atom is ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. The shape of an atom is determined by interactions of electrons, both shared and unshared, in the molecule. What best describes the attractive forces within and atom?

choice.choice: a. Electrons are strongly attracted to one another and repelled by the nucleus.
b. Electrons are strongly repelled from one another and are strongly attracted to the nucleus.
c. Electrons are neutral in their attractive forces regarding other particles in an atom.
d. Electrons are strongly repelled from the nucleus but are strongly attracted to the protons in an atom.

embeddable.name: 4. In the model of a Carbon ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. In the model of a Carbon 12 atom below, how many neutrons should there be?

embeddable.name: 5. In the model of the radioacti ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. In the model of the radioactive Carbon 14 atom below, how many neutrons should there be?

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Dissolving

embeddable.name: 1. What is meant by saying ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. What is meant by saying that a molecule is polar?

choice.choice: a. It aligns itself with the magnetic fields of the earth
b. It has two positive ends.
c. It has two negative ends.
d. It has both a negative and positive end.

embeddable.name: 2. Which substance is not ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. Which substance is not polar?

choice.choice: a. water
b. sugar
c. salt
d. oil

embeddable.name: 3. What happens to the temperatu ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. What happens to the temperature of water when you dissolve salt or sugar in it?

choice.choice: a. It will go up.
b. It will not change.
c. It will go down
d. It will go up initially and then go down.

embeddable.name: 4. Is the dissolving of sugar ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. Is the dissolving of sugar in water a chemical reaction?

choice.choice: a. Yes, because the sugar disappears into the water.
b. Yes, because the sugar changes its chemical composition.
c. No, because the sugar remains as crystals, though they are smaller.
d. No, because the sugar does not change its chemical composition.

choice.choice: a. It aligns itself with the magnetic fields of the earth

d. No, because the sugar does not change its chemical composition.

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Driving Forces of Reactions

embeddable.name: 1. If you had an Alka-Seltzer ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. If you had an Alka-Seltzer tablet and you wanted to speed up the chemical reaction, which would you choose to drop the tablet into?

choice.choice: a. cold water
b. room temperature water
c. hot water
d. any one of the above because there would be no difference

embeddable.name: 2. What does
embeddable.prompt: 2. What does not affect the equilibrium point of a chemical system?

choice.choice: a. pressure
b. shape of the container
c. temperature
d. number of molecules

embeddable.name: 3. What do we call a substance ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. What do we call a substance that is formed when the atoms of two or more elements bind together chemically?

choice.choice: a. a crystal
b. a compound
c. a mixture
d. an isotope

embeddable.name: 4. What is a process in which ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. What is a process in which atoms come together chemically to form a new substance?

choice.choice: a. association
b. dissociation
c. conglomeration
d. metamorphism

embeddable.name: 5. What is meant by the dissocia ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. What is meant by the dissociation energy?

choice.choice: a. the energy needed to bond atoms together
b. the energy needed to break a bond between atoms
c. the energy needed to melt a substance
d. the energy needed to break a crystalline structure

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Gas Laws

embeddable.name: 1. If you heat up a tin can, ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. If you heat up a tin can, seal it, and then place it in ice water, it collapses. Why is that?

choice.choice: a. There are fewer molecules when you cool it down.
b. The volume occupied by each molecule decreases.
c. The molecules slow down.
d. The molecules clump together.

embeddable.name: 2. If you wanted to double ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. If you wanted to double the pressure of a gas in a cylinder, what would you do?

choice.choice: a. Expand the cylinder to twice the volume.
b. Compress the cylinder to half the volume.
c. Double the temperature and let the cylinder expand.
d. Double the temperature and compress the cylinder to half the volume.

embeddable.name: 3. In a container with a ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. In a container with a fixed volume, how does increasing the kinetic energy of the gas molecules affect the temperature and the pressure?

choice.choice: a. It increases the temperature but not the pressure.
b. It increases the pressure but not the temperature.
c. It increases both temperature and pressure.
d. It increases the temperature and decreases the pressure.

embeddable.name: 4. In an expandable container, ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. In an expandable container, how can you increase the volume but keep the temperature and pressure constant?

choice.choice: a. The Ideal Gas Law states that you cannot do so.
b. Remove molecules.
c. Add molecules.
d. Increase the kinetic energy of the molecules.

embeddable.name: 1. If you heat up a tin can, ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. If you heat up a tin can, seal it, and then place it in ice water, it collapses. Why is that?

choice.choice: a. There are fewer molecules when you cool it down.

d. It increases the temperature and decreases the pressure.

embeddable.name: 4. In an expandable container, ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. In an expandable container, how can you increase the volume but keep the temperature and pressure constant?

choice.choice: a. The Ideal Gas Law states that you cannot do so.
b. Remove molecules.

section.name: Stoichiometry

embeddable.name: 1. In stoichiometry a balanced ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. In stoichiometry a balanced chemical equation is associated with a balance of what variable?

choice.choice: a. The starting and ending number of atoms
b. The starting and ending volume
c. The starting and ending number of molecules
d. The starting and ending temperature

embeddable.name: 2. In the diagram below, ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. In the diagram below, a reaction between nitrogen and hydrogen results in molecules of ammonia. What are the molecular coefficients?

embeddable.name: 3. How many molecules of ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. How many molecules of oxygen do you need to make 6 molecules of water?

embeddable.name: 4. Which type of atom not ...
embeddable.prompt:
4. Which type of atom not balanced in this equation?

AgNO3 + 2 HCl --> HNO3 + 2 AgCl

choice.choice: a. nitrogen
b. hydrogen
c. oxygen
d. chlorine

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Heat of Reaction

embeddable.name: 1. What is the difference ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. What is the difference between an endothermic and an exothermic reaction?

choice.choice: a. An endothermic reaction absorbs heat and an exothermic reaction produces heat.
b. An endothermic reaction produces heat and an exothermic reaction absorbs heat.
c. An endothermic reaction absorbs chemicals and an exothermic reaction produces chemicals.
d. An endothermic reaction produces gas and an exothermic reaction absorbs gas.

embeddable.name: 2. In a reaction that produces ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. In a reaction that produces energy, where does the energy come from?

choice.choice: a. The chemical bonds end up with more potential energy.
b. The products end up with less kinetic energy.
c. The chemical bonds end up with less potential energy.
d. In the end there are fewer chemical bonds.

embeddable.name: 3. In a reaction that produces ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. In a reaction that produces energy, in what form is the produced energy after the reaction?

choice.choice: a. activation energy
b. dissociation energy
c. potential energy of chemical bonds
d. kinetic energy of molecular motion

embeddable.name: 4. In this graph of a reaction, ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. In this graph of a reaction, which value represents the activation energy?

embeddable.name: 5. Which of the following ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. Which of the following is not an example of a chemical reaction?

choice.choice: a. Salt dissolves in water.
b. Yeast produces CO<sub>2</sub> in water.
c. Sugar is ground down to a fine powder.
d. A match is heated by friction and bursts into flame.

embeddable.name: 1. What is the difference ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. What is the difference between an endothermic and an exothermic reaction?

d. An endothermic reaction produces gas and an exothermic reaction absorbs gas.

choice.choice: a. activation energy

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Collisions

embeddable.name: 1.The goal of the activity ...
embeddable.prompt: 1.The goal of the activity below is to use the light ball to roll the heavy ball off the table. In order for that to happen, what would you would have to with the light ball?

choice.choice: a. Roll it slowly toward the heavier ball so it won’t just bounce off.
b. Roll it very fast towards the heavier ball to overcome its resistance to move.
c. Bounce the lighter ball towards the heavier ball so it will hit the ball from above.
d. A light object will always bounce off the much heavier object and will not move it.

embeddable.name: 2. A weight (yellow block) ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. A weight (yellow block) is thrown against a wall. What is the best explanation for what happens to the atoms in the wall (red and white circles) ?

choice.choice: a. The individual atoms are destroyed upon impact by the weight.
b. The individual atoms are set in motion and the temperature increases.
c. The weight bounces off the wall, so no energy is transferred.
d. The individual atoms slow down and absorb the impact of the weight.

embeddable.name: 3. If you let a pendulum ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. If you let a pendulum go from point 1, at what point will it have the maximum potential energy?

embeddable.name: 4. If you let a pendulum ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. If you let a pendulum go from point 1, at what point will it have the maximum kinetic energy?

embeddable.name: 5. This is a lump of clay ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. This is a lump of clay with a temperature sensor stuck into it, resting on a table top. What will happen to the temperature of the clay when hit by a book dropped on it?

choice.choice: a. The temperature of the clay will go down because the table will take the energy transferred from the book through the clay.
b. b. The clay will be physically flattened but won't change temperature.
c. The temperature of the clay will go up because the energy transferred to the clay will set the clay's atoms into motion.
d. The clay will transfer all the energy back into the book.

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Global Warming

embeddable.name: 1. How do greenhouse gases ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. How do greenhouse gases in the atmosphere contribute to warming of the earth's climate?

choice.choice: a. They reflect incoming solar radiation
a. They absorb incoming solar radiation
a. They absorb outgoing infrared radiation from the earth
a. They reflect back infrared radiation from the earth

embeddable.name: 2. What role do clouds play ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. What role do clouds play in the temperature of the earth’s climate?

choice.choice: a. Clouds reflect more incoming radiation than they allow through so they cool the earth.
a. Clouds absorb more incoming radiation than they reflect so they warm the earth.
a. Clouds reflect back large amounts of radiated energy from the oceans so they warm the earth.
a. Clouds have little effect on the radiated energy from the earth so there is no impact.

embeddable.name: 3. Here is a chart of the ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. Here is a chart of the earth's average temperature (blue) and the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere (green) over the last 400,000 years. This information is inferred from ice core samples taken in Antarctica. According to this chart, what is the relationship between carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere and the earth’s temperature?

choice.choice: a. The earth’s temperature seems to drop during high levels of carbon dioxide.
b. The earth’s temperature seems to increase during high levels of carbon dioxide.
c. There is no correlation between the earth’s temperature and carbon dioxide levels.
d. Higher average temperatures cause greater carbon dioxide levels.

embeddable.name: 4. The chart below shows ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. The chart below shows the different cycles of solar intensity over thousands of years (red, green, blue, yellow)) and the stages of glaciation on the earth (black). What can one conclude from this chart?

choice.choice: a. The sun is a very constant source of energy over the historical record.
b. Variations in the sun's intensity have no impact on the earth's climate.
c. There is a strong correlation between stages of glaciations and solar cycles.
d. There may be some correlation between the sun and the climatic cycles.

embeddable.name: 5. If the earth loses its ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. If the earth loses its polar ice and snow how could that affect the temperature of the earth?

choice.choice: a. Snow and ice reflect a large amount of the sunlight hitting it so the earth would warm up even more.
b. Snow and ice act as an insulating blanket on the earth trapping earth's energy from leaving, so it would the earth would cool.
c. Snow and ice absorb a tremendous amount of energy as they melt so they would heat the earth.
d. Snow and ice block large amounts of water from becoming snow and rain and its loss would mean the start of another ice age.

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Ramps and Friction

embeddable.name: 1. A skateboarder travels ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. A skateboarder travels without friction along a curved track. At what points is the skateboarders’ potential energy the greatest?

choice.choice: a. 1 and 2
b. 2 and 3
c. 3 and 4
d. 4 and 1

embeddable.name: 2. A skateboarder travels ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. A skateboarder travels without friction along a curved track. The skateboarder is now on Jupiter and the gravitational pull is almost 3 times stronger there. If the skate boarder started at point 1 what is going to happen?

choice.choice: a. The skateboarder is going to fly right past point 2.
b. The skateboarder is going to stop at the bottom because of the stronger gravity.
c. The skateboarder is going to skate up to 2 and back to point 1.
d. The skateboarder is going to skate up to 2 and make it only part way back to 1.

embeddable.name: 3. A skateboarder travels ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. A skateboarder travels without friction along a curved track. The skateboarder is now on the moon with only about 1/6 of the earth's gravity. If the skateboarder started at point 1 what is going to happen now when the boarder reaches point 2?

choice.choice: a. The boarder will fly off into space when the boarder reaches point 2.
b. The boarder will make it all the way to point 2 but will not have enough energy to come back down.
c. The boarder will make it all the way to point 2 and then back to point 1.
d. The boarder will not stay on the track because there's less gravity.

embeddable.name: 4. A toy car is given a sudden ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. A toy car is given a sudden push and then coasts to a stop on a level floor. What will the graph of distance look like?

choice.choice: a
b
c
d

embeddable.name: 5. A toy car is given a sudden ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. A toy car is given a sudden push and then coasts to a stop on a level floor. What will the graph of velocity look like?

choice.choice: a. A
b. B
c. C
d. D

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Electricity

embeddable.prompt: 1. This is a picture of a student’s effort to light a bulb with two batteries. What will happen when the switch is thrown on?

choice.choice: a. The light will turn on and stay on.
b. The light will turn on and then burn out.
c. The light will not go on.
d. The light will flicker and then go out.

embeddable.name: 2. The voltmeter reads 6 ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. The voltmeter reads 6 V. What would happen to the voltage if you added another battery of the same voltage in series with the other two?

choice.choice: a. The v would decrease to 3 V.
b. The voltage measure would remain 6 V.
c. The voltage would increase to 9 V.
d. The voltage would increase to 12 V.

embeddable.name: 3. Each of the two batteries ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. Each of the two batteries is 3 V. When we attach the lead of the voltmeter to the resister on the bottom what will the meter read?

choice.choice: a. 3 V
b. 6 V
c. 9 V
d. 12 V

embeddable.name: 4. Each of the batteries ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. Each of the batteries is 3 V. When the lead of the voltmeter is attached to the light bulb at the black arrow connection, what voltage will it read?

choice.choice: b. 3 V
c. 6 V
d. 12 V

embeddable.name: 5. If we touch the charged ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. If we touch the charged rod to the two pithballs what is going to happen?

choice.choice: a. The pithballs will move away from each other.
b. The pith balls will bounce against each other continuously.
c. The pith balls will burst into flame.
d. The pith balls will pull closer together.

embeddable.name: 6. Electrical current is ...
embeddable.prompt: 6. Electrical current is measured in what units?

choice.choice: a. Volts
b. Watts
c. Amperes
d. Newtons

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Waves

embeddable.name: 1.In comparing waves of two ...
embeddable.prompt: 1.In comparing waves of two different types, the frequency of a water wave is like what in light?

choice.choice: a. intensity
b. pulsing speed
c. color
d. velocity

embeddable.name: 2. What do we call the effect ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. What do we call the effect of waves bouncing off a barrier in front of them, as in the above model?

choice.choice: a. surf zone
b. refraction
c. reflection
d. interference

embeddable.name: 3. In this model of two sources ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. In this model of two sources of waves next to each other, what causes the pattern in the rings of waves?

choice.choice: a. The waves refract.
b. Some of the waves go faster than others.
c. The waves overlap and cancel or reinforce each other.
d. The frequencies of the two sources are different.

embeddable.name: 4. The model above shows ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. The model above shows a light emitter whose color and brightness can be changed. If we wanted to increase the distance between the peaks in the model, what would we do?

choice.choice: a. increase the brightness
b. move the color toward blue
c. decrease the brightness
d. move the color toward red

embeddable.name: 5. The chart shows a recording ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. The chart shows a recording of the vowel C using a microphone. The distance between point 1 and point 3 is called what?

choice.choice: a. the wavelength
b. the wave intensity
c. the wave frequency
d. the wave amplitude

embeddable.name: 6. The different colors on ...
embeddable.prompt: 6. The different colors on the CD are caused by what?

choice.choice: a. diffraction
b. interference
c. refraction
d. reflection

embeddable.name: 1.In comparing waves of two ...
embeddable.prompt: 1.In comparing waves of two different types, the frequency of a water wave is like what in light?

choice.choice: a. intensity
b. pulsing speed
c. color
d. velocity

embeddable.name: 2. What do we call the effect ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. What do we call the effect of waves bouncing off a barrier in front of them, as in the above model?

choice.choice: a. surf zone
b. refraction
c. reflection
d. interference

embeddable.name: 3. In this model of two sources ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. In this model of two sources of waves next to each other, what causes the pattern in the rings of waves?

choice.choice: a. The waves refract.
b. Some of the waves go faster than others.
c. The waves overlap and cancel or reinforce each other.
d. The frequencies of the two sources are different.

choice.choice: a. the wavelength

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Light and Matter

embeddable.name: 1. How do gas discharge lamps ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. How do gas discharge lamps work?

choice.choice: a. The electrode in the lamp excites the electrons in the gas to a higher energy level.
b. The electrode in the lamp glows brightly as it gets heated by an electric current.
c. The electrode in the lamp heats the gas so that it begins to move quickly and glows.
d. The electrode in the lamp creates a magnetic field that causes the gases to glow.

embeddable.name: 2. Here are the spectra from ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. Here are the spectra from four different gas discharge lamps. Which one will have the reddest light?

choice.choice: a. mercury
b. hydrogen
c. sodium
d. neon

embeddable.name: 3. Here is the spectrum of ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. Here is the spectrum of mercury. Why are there several individual colors instead of a continuous band?

choice.choice: a. Mercury is a heavy metal.
b. Only these colors can escape from the nucleus.
c. Mercury absorbs all the other wavelengths.
d. The energy difference between electon orbitals is not continuous.

embeddable.name: 4. When sunlight hits an ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. When sunlight hits an object and all of the light is reflected, what color will it appear to be?

choice.choice: a. black
b. white
c. red
d. green

embeddable.name: 5. If sunlight hits an object ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. If sunlight hits an object and every color except red is absorbed by the object, what color will the object appear to be?

choice.choice: a. black
b. white
c. red
d. green

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Magnetic Fields

embeddable.name: 1. The north pole of a compass ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. The north pole of a compass points north. What is the polarity of the earth's magnetic north pole?

choice.choice: a. north
b. south
c. east
d. west

embeddable.name: 2. In the diagram showing ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. In the diagram showing the magnetic field around a bar magnet, where is the field the weakest?

choice.choice: a. A
b. B
c. C
d. D

embeddable.name: 3. In this diagram of an ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. In this diagram of an electromagnet, where is the magnetic field the strongest?

embeddable.name: 4. The field inside the electrom ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. The field inside the electromagnet (white arrows) is measured as 100 Gauss. What would you do to change it to 50 Gauss?

choice.choice: a. Change the battery voltage to 10 V.
b. Change the number of turns in the coil to 4.
c. Change the number of turns in the coil to 1.
d. Reverse the polarity of the battery.

embeddable.name: 5. The battery creates a ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. The battery creates a magnetic field in the coil below it, but the light bulb does not light up. What would you do to make the bulb light up?

choice.choice: a. Move the two coils closer together.
b. Increase the number of turns in each coil.
c. Increase the voltage of the battery.
d. Quickly turn the battery on and off.

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Heat Transfer

embeddable.name: 1. Choose the feature that ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. Choose the feature that does not affect the rate of flow of heat through a material.

choice.choice: a. its heat capacity
b. the difference in temperature
c. its thermal conductivity
d. its reflectivity

embeddable.name: 2. Why does wood feel warmer ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. Why does wood feel warmer to the touch than metal?

choice.choice: a. It has a higher temperature.
b. It holds more heat.
c. It conducts heat more slowly.
d. It radiates less heat.

embeddable.name: 3. On a molecular level, ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. On a molecular level, how does heat travel through solids?

choice.choice: a. Hot molecules move through the material.
b. Faster-vibrating molecules hit slower-vibrating ones, passing the energy along.
c. The gas between the molecules carries the heat energy.
d. The hotter molecules radiate heat to the colder ones.

embeddable.name: 4. Here is a molecular model ...
embeddable.prompt:
4. Here is a molecular model of two objects (green and blue) connected by a conducting solid (orange).

The graph shows the temperatures of the two objects over time. If the orange solid connecting the green and blue objects were less conducting, how would the temperature graphs be different?

choice.choice: a. It would take longer for the two temperatures to approach each other.
b. the two temperatures would not approach each other.
c. The final temperature would be greater.
d. The final temperature would be less.

embeddable.name: 5. What is an example of ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. What is an example of heat transfer by radiation?

choice.choice: a. touching a hot stove
b. baking bread in an oven
c. toasting slices of bread in an electric toaster
d. boiling water on a gas stove
